Jan 2017 Links

January 2017 summary of my online reading

Media

Art

  • “Columnist Nat Hentoff dies at 91”
  • “The center of ‘Why’?”, Alan Kay, 2004.
  • “How ‘Sherlock of the library’ cracked the case of Shakespeare’s identity”

Education

  • “Text Your Way to College”, without help from knowledgeable guidance counselors, many high achievers from the bottom income quarter do not enroll. David L. Kirp suggest a text campaign.

Finance

  • “Poor Neighborhoods Make the Best Investments”
  • “How Space Could Trigger a Future Economic Crisis”

Op-Ed

  • “Confirm or Deny: Peter Thiel”

Science

  • “Just how smart is an octopus?”
  • “An asteroid just flew by Earth about 50% closer than the moon, and we barely saw it coming”
  • “The Detective of Northern Oddities”
  • “This Human-Powered Paper Centrifuge Is Pure Genius”
  • “Africa 'witnessing birth of a new ocean'”
  • “Female shark learns to reproduce without males after years alone”
  • “Is the Default Mode of the Brain to Suffer?”
  • “America's Long-Overdue Opioid Revolution Is Finally Here”
  • “The Heroism of Incremental Care”

Security

  • “The Unraveling of Julian Assange”
  • “The Swedish Kings of Cyberwar”

Tech

  • “Facebook will lose 80% of users by 2017, say Princeton researchers“. Forecast of social network's impending doom comes from comparing its growth curve to that of an infectious disease.
  • “My WATCH runs GNU/Linux And It Is Amazing”
  • “Venture capital is going to murder Medium”
  • “Google Brain Residency Program - 7 months in and looking ahead ”
  • “Chernobyl's new sarcophagus”, BBC. hernobyl’s giant New Safe Confinement (NSC) was moved over a distance of 327 metres from its assembly point to its final resting place, completely enclosing a previous makeshift shelter that was hastily assembled immediately after the 1986 accident. A great showcase of human engineering. Link to the video, Wikipedia article and a detailed storyline.
  • “The History of the iPhone, On Its 10th Anniversary”
  • “All of Human Knowledge Buried in a Salt Mine”

Misc

  • “The Japanese Art of Grieving a Miscarriage”
  • “Dropped”, why did Anthony Gatto, the greatest juggler alive—and perhaps of all time—back away from his art to open a construction business?
  • “Iceland knows how to stop teen substance abuse”

Reporting

  • “The spy with no name”

Blogs

AI

  • “The science of Westworld”
  • “GTA V + Universe”

Art

  • “Lecture On Creativity”, John Cleese.

Computer Science

  • “Myths about /dev/urandom”, Thomas Hühn argues that /dev/urandom is insecure. Always use /dev/random for cryptographic purposes.
  • “Symbolic mathematics on Linux”, this article is an introduction to the world of free and open-source applications for symbolic mathematics. These are programs that allow to manipulate mathematical expressions.
  • “Bitpacking and Compression of Sparse Datasets”
  • “Distributing NixOS With IPFS - Part 1”
  • “Linux Performance”

ML

  • “king - man + woman is queen; but why?”, Piotr Migdał. word2vec is an algorithm that transforms words into vectors.

Science

  • “How the Human Brain Decides What Is Important and What’s Not”
  • “One Man’s Quest to Hack His Own Genes”
  • “Stepping into math: Open-sourcing our step-by-step solver”
  • “Two Infants Treated with Universal Immune Cells Have Their Cancer Vanish”
  • “Paralyzed man regains use of arms and hands after experimental stem cell therapy at Keck Hospital of USC”

Programming

  • “Go and Dogma”
  • “Rust vs. Go”
  • “‘How’ ages faster than ‘Why’
  • “Uninitialized Reads: Understanding the proposed revisions to the C language”

Misc

  • “Crowdsourcing moderation without sacrificing quality”
  • “What I Wish I'd Known About Equity Before Joining A Unicorn”
  • “Making it in Japan―The Story of Starting a Business in Japan”
  • “How We’re Building a Business to Last”

Books, Stories & essays

  • “The Immortal Bard”, Isaac Asimov.

Websites

  • “The Kitten Programming Language”. Kitten is a statically typed, stack-based functional programming language designed to be simple and fast. It is a concatenative language, combining aspects of imperative and pure functional programming.
  • “Brainfilling Curves”
  • “Pplapi: A virtual database of the entire human population”

Scientific papers

  • “Neural Architecture Search with Reinforcement Learning”

Random

  • “Nicaraguan Sign Language”
